children.subject:
Idk what Rajit is saying but in my experience especially if looking for return offers/reccomendations you end up doing much more than 4 hours a week at the minimum.

Please don't be a disservice to both your students and your research by not doing well in both. A lot of 61c TAs this past semester had other obligations which left the state of the class as a huge mess.

It is obviously all worth it (hence why op is asking) but it clearly too much as there are only 24 hours in a day. Something has to be cut as people have other needs as well other than working 24/7...

It goes both ways. Classes shouldn't expect TAs to also work above the minimum of 8 hours either. If that happens, then the head TAs + professors are clearly doing something wrong. Also generally, TAs do have other obligations. Generally speaking, teaching isn't their primary goal. That is not to say, they shouldn't try their best to teach, its just inherently TAs will have other obligations.

I think its definitely worth it! Although it wont be easy. 8 hour TAs are often more like 4 hours of work at the minimum.

Edit: As long as you get your share of the work done, I dont see why the number of hours you put in matters? Its always good to go above and beyond if possible. I wasn't part of 61C course staff so I can't comment on that.

history.content:
I think it depends what your goals are. First, the workload will vary depending on the course. Some factors that you should take into account are whether the course reuses projects/how well you remember material. If a course tends to not re-use a project, that means more hours for you to prepare for that. An 8 hour position can turn into several hours more per week because you have to do the next project to prepare for OH, etc. I personally would not recommend TAing a course which updates their projects every semester (i.e. CS61B/C) unless you can dedicate the time to do each project.

As to whether its worth it, it depends on your goals and what you want to get out of it. Is your goal graduate school? TAing won't really help with that. In which case, do NOT TA if it gets in the way of your current research. If you want to TA because you enjoy teaching? Absolutely yes! There are some great things you can learn from TAing, like presentation skills, public speaking, etc.  

source: phd student, who TA'd several lower/upper div courses here

I think it sometimes depends what your goals are. First, the workload will vary depending on the course. Some factors that you should take into account are whether the course reuses projects/how well you remember material. If a course tends to not re-use a project, that means more hours for you to prepare for that. An 8 hour position can turn into several hours more per week because you have to do the next project to prepare for OH, etc. I personally would not recommend TAing a course which updates their projects every semester (i.e. CS61B/C) unless you can dedicate the time to do each project.

As to whether its worth it, it depends on your goals and what you want to get out of it. Is your goal graduate school? TAing won't really help with that. In which case, do NOT TA if it gets in the way of your current research. If you want to TA because you enjoy teaching? Absolutely yes! There are some great things you can learn from TAing, like presentation skills, public speaking, etc.

children.subject: It can help if it somehow assists you in finding research, getting letters of rec, etc. (this was my experience). But the most important thing in general for PhD admissions at least is undergrad research experience. So, if you're spending a lot of time on TA duties instead of research, it is actively detrimental in that sense.
That is good to know. What do you recommend to do as an undergraduate student if I want to pursue a master's degree?

For a research-oriented master's (e.g. nominally the 5th Year MS), the same advice for the PhD basically applies. For any other master's, you should look at it in the same way you would look to prepare a resume for a job application in industry really. If doing research actively furthers your career goals, then it definitely makes sense to prioritize that. Being a TA will build your presentation skills and build competency in the subject matter you are teaching, so if you think that will be more helpful (e.g. for an interview, or just fundamental knowledge), then doing that makes sense.

I guess one important thing in general is that classes are so large here at Cal that getting letters of rec can be very tough. Research will get you at least one good letter of rec (hopefully), but TAing for multiple professors can get you more "just OK" letters. I'm not sure what the best optimization is, but it's something to consider. 

Letters of rec are also much more significant for applications to research-oriented degrees.

I would go far as to say that TA letters can be worth very little if you don't have any letters from a professor that speaks to your research performance. Some advisors here discourage students from TAing as it takes time away from research. I don't think TAing for multiple professors will create a strong profile for graduate applications in the end if your goal is to aim for top PHD programs. I would not TA for the sake of getting better recommendations.

I guess I will qualify my statement in the sense that being a TA only helped me get a possibly good letter in one case, where I was basically the head/admin TA for a small upper-division course taught by one professor that was also familiar with me previously.

After I TAed for 61C, for example, I took an upper-div with one of the professors I TAed with, and he not only had no clue who I was, but he also asked me multiple times in class if I had taken 61C before when I asked some clarifying questions.

Obviously, this shouldn't predict anyone else's experience, and I never had any intention of asking this professor for a letter of rec, but this should show that context always matters (in this case, huge lower-div with a developed teaching staff hierarchy vs. small upper-div where I was the teaching staff hierarchy).
Why doesn't TA'ing help if someone's goal is graduate school?

I've been in a similar position (8 hour TA for 61C) and I definitely was not able to continue putting the same effort into my research once the semester got underway. I managed to make reasonable progress basically by working non-stop on certain weekends and Thanksgiving, and it's not really what I would call "thriving". 

TAing can be a very rewarding experience, but if your goal is a PhD and the fee remission isn't a huge incentive for you, then I would definitely advise you to not take on too much. Certainly, if you do a PhD, you will have many opportunities to TA then, and it won't be such a scheduling headache. 

If you're seriously considering TAing now and you can afford to scale back on your research duties, then you can try it, but your experience could be similar to my own.

history.content:
I am an incoming junior planning on taking 106a, 151, and a humanities in the fall. I am also doing research seriously (about 15 hours a week). I recently received an 8 hour/week GSI position, but am worried if I will be able to handle the workload. Can anyone advice on if you think this workload is manageable or not? 

Thanks!
history.subject: Advice on taking a TA position
